div1.p: Dr. H.R. Carter Claimed By Death

div1.head: Newspaper clipping, The Sun, Baltimore, September 14, 1925
div1.p:
DR. H. R. CARTER
CLAIMED BY DEATH

Former Assistant Surgeon
General of Health Service
Dies at Age of 73.

Dr. Henry R. Carter, 73 years old,
former Assistant Surgeon General of
the United States Public Health
Service, and considered one of the
foremost medical and sanitary spe-
cialists in the country, died at the
Westmoreland apartments, 2122 Cali-
fornia street, today after a lingering
illness.

He was born in Clifton Plantation,
Carolina County, Va., Auugst 25, 1852.
He was commissioned in the United
States Marine hospital service, now
the public health Service. May
5, 1879. He served as chief quar-
antine officer of the Island of Cuba
from January, 1899, until August,
1900, and as chief quarantine officer
of the Isthmian Canal commission
from May, 1904, until February, 1905,
when he became director of hospitals
of the Isthmian Canal commission,
serving in this capacity from March,
1905, until September, 1909. He served
at different times as sanitary super-
visor to the Peruvian government and
as a member of the international
health board of the Rockefeller Foun-
dation up until the time of his death.
He retired July, 1920.

Among the most notable of his sani-
tary and scientific achievements were
the determination of the period of ex-
trinsic incubation of yellow fever, a
foundation on which the brilliant work
of Walter Reed and his commission
rested and for which Dr. Carter was
nominated for the Nobel prize by the
__________________________________________________
distinguished English physician and
sanitarian, Maj.Sir Ronald Ross.

He was the founder of the present
maritime quarantine system of the
United States. Dr. Carter served in
and dominated many outbreaks of yel-
low feved epidemics in the Southern
States, including that of MacHenry,
Miss, the first outbreak of this disease
which was controlled during the Sum-
mer months; inaugurated the quaran-
tine systems of Cuba and the Canal
ports.

He enunciated the principles relat-
ing to the bearing of the impounding
of great bodies of waters on the pro-
duction of malaria, a matter in which
the economic future of many parts of
our Southern States is bound up.

He inaugurated control measures
for malaria in the extra cantonment
areas of Army camps in malarial
regions during the World War. He
was a member of many scientific
bodies relating to medicine and
hygiene, both American and foreign.
He formulated the doctrine of the
control of the yellow fever bearing
mosquito as the sole method necessary
for the elimination of endemic centers
of this disease.

He was intimately associated with
Gen. Gorgas and Col. Walter Reed
throughout the greater parts of their
careers, particularly in the work,
study and control of yellow fever. It
is doubtful if modern science records
a like example of men of kindred
sympathies and almost common birth
whose labors in the same field of
endeavor yielded such notable results.

The funeral services will take place
__________________________________________________
at 10 o'clock Wednesday morning at
the Westmoreland, and later at St.
Margaret's Church. Archdeacon
Sterling Claiborne of Sewanee, Tenn.,
and Rev. Dr. Smith of St. Margaret's
Church will conduct the funeral serv-
ices. Relatives, friends and officers
of the service will accompany the
body on the noon train Wednesday to
Ashland. Va., its final resting place,
beside his wife, who died a number of
years ago.
